Comments_List: I improved my Kiswahili and learned a lot about cultures and communities in East Africa, especially women.
I improved my grammar and writing.
I learned some talking and comprehension skills

The class is very friendly and the professor makes an effort to engage everyone and is honest. She listens to the class and took our feedback on the class into account. I felt that writing and reading preparation was strong.

I wished we could have done more listening practice as I still really struggle with that.
Stength was reading and writing. I wiuld suggest more oral practice and drilling.
Talking with eachother more in swahili would be really useful. In addition, both the teacher and the students should have spoken more in swahili. The quizes should be more frequent as well
There is too much speaking in English.  This is an intermediate class, it should be almost entirely in Swahili.

Yes! I really enjoyed this class. The workload was less than other classes because you do so much work in the class which makes the class itself feel worthwhile as opposed to just being a place to demonstrate knowledge you acquired elsewhere. I really liked coming into class and experimenting with the language. It was probably my favorite class.
Depending on the students interestes in learning swahili - this is the place to do that

Yes, because it's fun and easy to learn.  But the class could be so much better; we barely speak in Swahili.  We need to speak in Swahili every class.  I would recommend we start every class with a 10 minute conversation with the person sitting next to us, all in Swahili, where we answer some question or just talk about what we did yesterday.  That would make this course so much better.
